name: Sandy, Swinton, Shakespeare and Derek
description: Tracing costume designer Sandy Powell's ongoing connections with Tilda Swinton, William Shakespeare and Derek Jarman.

key_work.title: Sandy Powell’s costume designs
key_work.brief_description: Costume designer Sandy Powell begins her design process with the script, and then consults with directors on how they envision the characters. Next step is choosing fabrics – one of the most important parts of her process because it inspires the costumes.

end.title: The Tempest
end.creator_credit: Jason K. Lau, Julia Taylor-Stanley, Julie Taymor, Lynn Hendee and Robert Chartoff
end.brief_description: An adaptation of the play by William Shakespeare. Prospera (a female version of Shakespeare’s Prospero) is the usurped ruler of Milan who has been banished to a mysterious island with her daughter. Using her magical powers, she draws her enemies to the island to exact her revenge.

links.description: Sandy Powell’s punk-infused designs for Julie Taymor’s production of The Tempest echoed the punk sensibility of her friend Derek Jarman’s 1980s adaptation.

end.title: Orlando

end.headline_credit: France, Italy, Netherlands, Russia and United Kingdom, 1993
end.brief_description: In 1600, nobleman Orlando (Tilda Swinton) inherits his parents’ house, thanks to Queen Elizabeth I (Quentin Crisp), who commands the young man to never change.

constellations_other.description: Tracing costume designer Sandy Powell's ongoing connections with Tilda Swinton, William Shakespeare and Derek Jarman.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the binary
constellations_other.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

links.description: In designing costumes for The Favourite, Sandy Powell found herself unconsciously quoting her previous work on Sally Potter’s Orlando. No surprise, as both were filmed at Hatfield House and feature early to mid-18th century fashion.

end.title: Shakespeare in Love
end.creator_credit: David Parfitt, Donna Gigliotti, Edward Zwick, Harvey Weinstein and Marc Norman
end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 1998
end.brief_description: Young Shakespeare is forced to stage his latest comedy, “Romeo and Ethel, the Pirate’s Daughter,” before it’s even written. When a lovely noblewoman auditions for a role, they fall into forbidden love — and his play finds a new life (and title). As their relationship progresses, Shakespeare’s comedy soon transforms into tragedy.

links.description: Sandy Powell went from designing costumes from a film about Shakespeare, to a film (based on a play) written by Shakespeare.
